+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**SCP-XXXX Incident Report** **Researcher: Dr. Elias Mercer** **Date: [REDACTED]** **Assigned Site: Site-██** --- I don't know when it started. The first note was innocuous—just a single line on a scrap of paper atop my desk: *"Check the locks on SCP-███'s containment."* I assumed I had written it myself and simply forgotten. A reasonable conclusion. Our work is stressful, and memory lapses are common. I double-checked the locks, found nothing amiss, and moved on. But then there was another. *"You need to listen. It's going to happen soon."* This one was different. It was in my handwriting, but the ink was still drying when I picked it up. I hadn't written it. I reported the anomaly to Site Director Halloway. Protocol dictated an investigation: security footage, fingerprints, handwriting analysis. The cameras, however, were useless. Each time a note appeared, the feed glitched—static bursts just long enough to obscure the moment of arrival. No unauthorized personnel had accessed my office. The only fingerprints on the notes were mine. --- **Note Fragment — Date: [REDACTED]** *"They're lying to you. Don't trust the logs. The breach ALREADY happened."* --- My colleagues grew concerned. Dr. Patel suggested stress-induced hallucinations. I wanted to believe that. But hallucinations don’t leave behind physical evidence. The notes kept coming. They became longer, more desperate. Some described events that hadn’t occurred—containment failures, personnel deaths, evacuation alarms. I cross-referenced every detail, but reality remained unchanged. Then the contradictions started. One note warned me that SCP-███ had breached containment and killed three researchers. The next insisted no breach had occurred, that the real danger was something else—something unnamed but imminent. I began questioning my own perceptions. I would leave my desk for minutes and return to find a new note waiting. I started keeping a live camera feed on my workstation, but the glitches persisted. No visible hand placed the notes. They simply *were.* --- **Note Fragment — Date: [REDACTED]** *"I can’t stop it. It already happened, it's happening, it WILL happen. Elias, PLEASE. You have to listen. You have to—"* (Handwriting becomes erratic. Ink smeared. Unreadable past this point.) --- The Foundation intensified its investigation. A memetic analysis ruled out cognitohazardous influence. Temporal anomalies were considered, but no other signs of time displacement were detected. Some theorized that an unknown entity—possibly one already in containment—was manipulating my perception or inserting these messages deliberately. I was placed under observation. Medical scans showed no abnormalities. Psychological assessments were inconclusive. I wasn’t losing time. I wasn’t dissociating. *But the notes kept coming.* I began experimenting. I left sheets of blank paper on my desk before leaving my office. Upon return, a note would be there, written in my hand but with words I had never formed. One day, I tried writing back. *"Who are you?"* I left the question on my desk and stepped away, watching the live feed from another room. The camera glitched for precisely 2.3 seconds. When the feed cleared, my paper had a response: *"You know who I am. You have to stop this."* --- **Note Fragment — Date: [REDACTED]** *"They won’t believe you. They never did. You have to RUN."* --- I stopped sleeping. I stopped trusting my own thoughts. I would catch myself hesitating before speaking, before writing, afraid that my own words might be turned against me. Then came the final note. It wasn’t left on my desk like the others. It was in my pocket, crumpled and damp with sweat. I don’t remember putting it there. I don’t remember reaching for it. But when I unfolded it, I recognized my writing. *"The next note will be the last. You won’t remember writing it. You won’t remember why. But when you see it, you’ll know what to do."* I still don’t know if I wrote it. Maybe I did. Maybe I didn’t. The last note appeared three hours later. It simply read: *"It’s too late."* Then, the alarms sounded. --- **Post-Incident Analysis:** At 03:17 AM, SCP-███ initiated an unexpected containment breach. Three personnel were killed before recontainment was achieved. Notably, some details of the event aligned with warnings from the earlier notes, while others contradicted them entirely. Dr. Mercer was found in his office, unresponsive but physically unharmed. After regaining consciousness, he exhibited signs of acute paranoia and memory fragmentation. He was placed under medical observation. Security footage continued to show unexplained glitches at the moments when notes appeared. No external entity has been identified as responsible. Investigation into the nature of this anomaly remains ongoing. The possibility of a retrocausal event, psychological manipulation, or an unknown memetic influence has not been ruled out. Dr. Mercer has been temporarily relieved of duty pending further evaluation. When asked if he had any final comments regarding the incident, he provided only one statement: *"I think I was trying to warn myself. I just don’t know if I ever stood a chance of listening."*
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The test model has created a compelling SCP report that effectively captures the essence of the SCP Foundation's clinical yet unsettling documentation style. The piece successfully implements the first-person perspective of the researcher as requested, interspersed with note fragments that create a sense of mounting dread and temporal confusion. The narrative structure works well for the SCP format, beginning with seemingly innocuous notes that gradually become more disturbing and desperate. The model has created a genuinely unsettling scenario where the protagonist cannot trust their own perception or even their own handwriting. The temporal paradox is handled with appropriate ambiguity - we never get a definitive answer about whether this is truly a message from the future or some form of manipulation, which maintains the mystery central to good SCP entries. The prose is appropriately clinical when describing Foundation protocols and more emotionally charged when conveying the researcher's deteriorating mental state. This balance helps maintain the SCP tone while still allowing for character development. The formatting with redactions, note fragments, and the post-incident analysis effectively mimics authentic SCP documentation. Where the piece could be improved is in its development of secondary characters. Dr. Patel and Site Director Halloway are mentioned but remain flat figures. The narrative also relies somewhat heavily on telling rather than showing the researcher's deteriorating mental state in places. While phrases like "I stopped sleeping. I stopped trusting my own thoughts" directly communicate the character's condition, more sensory details or specific incidents might have made this deterioration more visceral. The ending effectively delivers on the promised containment breach while maintaining ambiguity about the nature of the anomaly. The final statement from Dr. Mercer provides a poignant conclusion that reinforces the futility and circular nature of the temporal paradox. The piece successfully creates a sense of paranoia and existential dread appropriate to the SCP universe. The researcher's gradual loss of trust in reality and self is well-portrayed, and the clinical framing device of the SCP report format provides an effective contrast to the increasingly desperate notes. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 82.5
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Item #:** SCP-XXXX **Object Class:** Euclid **Special Containment Procedures:** Instances of SCP-XXXX are to be secured under Foundation control as soon as they are discovered. Mobile Task Force Mu-17 ("Archivists") is assigned to monitor known locations and intercept any unauthorized access. Any civilians who enter SCP-XXXX are to be detained, interrogated, and amnesticized as necessary. Exploration of SCP-XXXX is to continue under strict authorization. Personnel encountering foreign entities within the anomaly are to observe from a distance and report all findings immediately. Any documentation retrieved from SCP-XXXX must be cataloged and stored within Site-81’s restricted archives. **Description:** SCP-XXXX refers to a series of identical, unmarked wooden doors that manifest within abandoned buildings worldwide. These doors are uniform in design, appearing heavily worn but structurally intact regardless of local conditions. When closed, SCP-XXXX exhibits no anomalous properties, but when opened, it leads to an expansive extradimensional archive (designated SCP-XXXX-1). SCP-XXXX-1 is an enormous, non-Euclidean space resembling an archival repository extending far beyond observable limits. The architecture is inconsistent with any known style, incorporating elements from multiple historical periods and civilizations, often in contradictory arrangements. The air inside SCP-XXXX-1 is cool and dry, with a faint luminescence emanating from an unknown source. Documents found within SCP-XXXX-1 reference an advanced civilization predating recorded human history. These documents detail a highly developed society that was ultimately destroyed following an unspecified "containment failure." Among the recovered materials are references to an organization remarkably similar to the SCP Foundation, though under the name **"The Aegis Directive."** Personnel records discovered include names identical to current Foundation staff, dated centuries prior. ### **Exploration Log XXXX-07** **Date:** ██/██/████ **Exploration Team:** MTF Mu-17 **Lead Operative:** Agent L. Carter **Objective:** Investigate anomalous activity within SCP-XXXX-1 following reports of missing sections. **[BEGIN LOG]** **Agent Carter:** We’ve entered through the designated door in ████████, Poland. Archive structure appears unchanged. Temperature remains constant. Proceeding east down the main corridor. **Agent Ruiz:** Noting significant gaps in shelving here. This whole row is empty, like something’s been removed. **Agent Carter:** Confirmed. I see drag marks on the floor, like something heavy was moved recently. **Agent Singh:** Hold up. Lights ahead. Three figures in yellow hazmat suits. They’re moving crates. **Agent Carter:** Stay quiet. Observe. **[The team remains in cover, watching as the entities methodically remove documents from a nearby section. They work in silence, moving with mechanical efficiency.]** **Agent Carter:** They’re stripping this section clean. What's in those boxes? **Agent Ruiz:** Hard to tell, but some of the files they're packing have the Aegis Directive logo. **Agent Singh:** They saw us! They’re moving out! **[The entities immediately cease activity upon noticing the team. Without hesitation, they retreat deeper into SCP-XXXX-1, hauling their cargo with them. One entity deliberately tips over a shelf behind them, blocking pursuit.]** **Agent Carter:** Dammit, they knew we were coming. Let’s check what’s left. **[The team examines the remaining shelves, retrieving scattered documents overlooked by the entities.]** **[END LOG]** ### **Recovered Document XXXX-07-3** **Document Title:** **"Final Containment Assessment – The Aegis Directive"** **Date:** **[Illegible]** **Excerpt:** > "...despite our efforts, the breach expanded beyond projected limits. The entity’s influence is irreversible, and the Directive's control is no longer assured. The Council has convened in secret. Decisions must be made regarding survival, continuity, and memory integrity. If you are reading this, then we have failed." > "The next iteration must do better." --- ### **Exploration Log XXXX-12** **Date:** ██/██/████ **Exploration Team:** MTF Mu-17 **Lead Operative:** Agent L. Carter **Objective:** Investigate reports of unauthorized personnel within SCP-XXXX-1. **[BEGIN LOG]** **Agent Carter:** Entering SCP-XXXX-1 through the ███████ instance. We've received intel suggesting unauthorized access. Proceeding with caution. **Agent Ruiz:** Footsteps in the dust ahead. Multiple individuals. Someone's been through here recently. **Agent Singh:** Over here—found an open folder. Looks like a personnel file. **Agent Carter:** Read it. **Agent Singh:** Name: ████████. Position: **Overseer Council, Seat 5.** Date of Appointment: [Long before the current Foundation’s existence]. **Agent Carter:** That’s impossible. O5-5 is alive right now. **Agent Ruiz:** There’s another one. O5-7. Same kind of file, same dating problem. **Agent Carter:** Someone in the Council has been coming here. They knew about this place before we did. **[A distant noise is heard—like a heavy door closing.]** **Agent Carter:** Move. Someone’s here. **[The team advances, weapons ready, but upon reaching the corridor’s end, they find only a dimly lit stairwell descending into darkness. Faint footprints lead downward before abruptly stopping mid-step, as if the individuals vanished.]** **Agent Ruiz:** No sign of them. They were just here. **Agent Carter:** We need to report this immediately. The Council knows something they’re not telling us. **[END LOG]** ### **Recovered Document XXXX-12-5** **Document Title:** **"Council Mandate – Operation Continuity"** **Date:** **Undetermined** **Excerpt:** > "The Directive will survive, even if the world does not. The Archive is the failsafe—a testament to what was and what may yet be again. We will not repeat the same mistakes." > "The doors will open when the time is right." --- ### **Addendum XXXX-3: Unauthorized Access Investigation** Following the events of Exploration Log XXXX-12, security measures have been reinforced around all known SCP-XXXX instances. Surveillance has failed to capture any unauthorized personnel entering or exiting, yet evidence of recent activity continues to be discovered within SCP-XXXX-1. Attempts to directly contact the O5 Council regarding the findings have been met with dismissal or redacted responses. Further investigations are ongoing. **Closing Note:** The existence of SCP-XXXX-1 suggests that the SCP Foundation, or a version of it, has existed far longer than previously believed. The implications of this discovery, as well as the identities of the entities removing documents, remain unknown. It is unclear whether SCP-XXXX-1 is a record of the past, a warning for the future, or something else entirely.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response creates a compelling SCP entry that effectively captures the distinctive style and format of the SCP Foundation's fictional documentation. The piece successfully incorporates all the key elements requested in the prompt: unmarked doors in abandoned buildings, an impossible archive, references to a previous civilization destroyed by containment failure, personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago, hazmat teams removing documents, and unauthorized O5 Council visits. The structure follows SCP convention with containment procedures, description, exploration logs, and recovered documents. This format works well to build the mystery gradually through different perspectives and information sources. The exploration logs effectively convey the team's discoveries through dialogue and action, creating tension when they encounter the hazmat entities and evidence of O5 involvement. The writing establishes a consistent clinical tone appropriate for SCP documentation while still conveying the unsettling implications of the discoveries. The concept of "The Aegis Directive" as a previous iteration of the Foundation adds depth to the worldbuilding and creates an intriguing mystery about cyclical civilizational collapse. However, there are some missed opportunities for deeper exploration. The hazmat teams feel somewhat generic, and their motivations remain entirely unexplained. The piece could have benefited from more specific details about the architectural impossibilities of the archive beyond vague descriptions of "non-Euclidean space" and "contradictory arrangements." The recovered documents, while thematically appropriate, are brief and somewhat vague, missing chances to provide more specific and unsettling details about the previous civilization's downfall. The exploration logs effectively convey the team's discoveries but could have included more vivid sensory details to enhance immersion. The dialogue is functional but occasionally feels stilted with lines like "They knew we were coming. Let's check what's left" that don't fully capture the tension of the moment. Overall, the response successfully creates an intriguing SCP entry with the requested elements and maintains the appropriate tone and format throughout. It effectively establishes mystery and unease while leaving room for further exploration, which is appropriate to the SCP format. The piece balances exposition and action well, though it could have pushed further in developing unique details and more vivid descriptions. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 77.8
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter Seven: The Streets of Callis** The air of Callis hung thick with the scent of unfamiliar spices and the faint, metallic tang of the planet’s native flora. Envoy Senna Tain moved through the market streets alone, the diplomatic insignia on their collar tucked discreetly under a fold of fabric. It was against protocol, of course. But protocol was an instrument of control, and control was not understanding. The official briefings spoke of Callis-4 as a colony in crisis, its human population diverging after generations of isolation and environmental adaptation. The reports were dense with terms like *speciation drift* and *cultural schisms*, but they were written by bureaucrats who had never walked these streets, never seen the people who lived here. Senna had expected division, stratification, perhaps open hostility between the subspecies. What they found instead was something more complex, something that resisted the sharp lines drawn in government memos. The market bustled with activity, but it was not the chaos of an unruly colony. Vendors called out in a melodic dialect, their voices rising and falling in a cadence that seemed almost choreographed. Stalls displayed handwoven fabrics dyed in pigments not found on Earth—deep blues that shimmered like oil on water, reds that held an almost luminous intensity. An older woman, her skin mottled with the faint iridescence that marked those born on Callis, met Senna’s gaze and smiled, offering a length of cloth without a word. Senna ran their fingers over the weave. It was finer than anything they had seen in the trade delegations, more intricate than the samples presented to the diplomatic corps. The colonies were always more than their reports. "You carry yourself like an offworlder," the woman observed. Her voice was warm, but there was an edge to her words, a testing. "I am," Senna admitted. The woman nodded, as if this confirmed something she had already known. She did not ask Senna’s purpose or allegiance, only gestured toward the fabric. "A gift, if you wish it. For seeing the streets with your own eyes." Senna hesitated. A gift was never just a gift in diplomacy. But here, among these people who were meant to be splintering apart, there was an offer of understanding. They took the cloth and folded it carefully into their satchel before making their way back toward the administrative sector. ### The reprimand came swiftly. "You were observed outside the designated diplomatic quarters," Command’s voice crackled over the secure channel the moment Senna entered their assigned residence. "Explain yourself." "I was gathering information," Senna replied evenly. "The official reports do not align with the realities on the ground." "That is not your concern," Command snapped. "Your concern is maintaining protocol and securing cooperation from the Minister of Science. You are to meet with Minister Kelyr within the hour. See to it that you do not deviate from your assignment again." The transmission ended without further preamble. Senna exhaled slowly. Kelyr. A political appointee, not a scientist. That meant this meeting would be more test than discussion. They straightened their jacket, tucked away the market fabric, and left for the ministerial offices. ### Minister Kelyr occupied a sunlit chamber lined with records—some in digital form, others bound in the traditional Callis style, their covers embossed with sigils that denoted authorship and lineage. He was a tall man, his features bearing the subtle adaptations common to those born on Callis: slightly elongated fingers, a faint shift in the shape of the brow ridge. Not enough to constitute a separate species, not yet. But enough for Earth to be wary. "You’ve been walking the streets," Kelyr said as soon as Senna entered. His tone was not accusatory, but neither was it welcoming. He gestured toward a chair. "Sit." Senna did. "You are young," Kelyr observed. "And yet they have sent you to negotiate terms that will shape the future of Callis. Do you understand why?" Senna met his gaze. "Because I am untested, and therefore expendable." Kelyr smiled, though there was no mirth in it. "Good. You are not naïve. That will serve you well, if you survive long enough to be of consequence." He leaned forward. "Tell me what you saw in the streets." Senna did not answer immediately. This was a test, but of what kind? Kelyr already knew the answer; he would not have asked otherwise. "I saw a people far less divided than Earth believes," Senna said slowly. "I saw cooperation where I was told to expect schism. I saw a culture that is evolving, not fragmenting." Kelyr studied them for a long moment. Then he nodded. "Earth fears what it does not control," he said. "They send you to ensure that Callis does not slip beyond their grasp. But you have seen the truth: we are no longer a colony. We are something else now." Senna chose their next words carefully. "And what is it that Callis wants?" Kelyr leaned back, fingers tapping against the armrest of his chair. "That depends on whether Earth is willing to accept that we are not merely an extension of their dominion. We are changing, Envoy Tain. And change is always met with fear by those who wish the universe to remain as it was." Senna understood the unspoken warning. Earth had sent them to negotiate, but it had also sent them to judge. To determine whether Callis could be brought back into alignment, or whether more forceful measures would be required. "You walk a fine line, Minister," Senna said. Kelyr smiled again, this time with something closer to amusement. "As do you, Offworlder." He gestured toward the door. "Go now. Consider what you have seen, and what you will tell your superiors. But remember this: the future belongs to those who shape it. Not to those who fear it." Senna rose and left without another word. The weight of the cloth in their satchel felt heavier now. A gift, or a burden? Only time would tell.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures many elements of Ursula K. Le Guin's style, particularly her focus on anthropological observation and the tension between cultures. The writing presents a diplomatic scenario with nuanced political undertones, exploring themes of adaptation, cultural evolution, and the fear of difference. The protagonist, Envoy Senna Tain, is portrayed with appropriate complexity for a Le Guin character - observant, thoughtful, and caught between duty and personal ethics. Their decision to walk the streets against protocol feels authentic to the genre and serves the narrative purpose well. The prose has a measured quality reminiscent of Le Guin, with careful attention to sensory details like the "metallic tang of the planet's native flora" and fabrics with colors "not found on Earth." These details effectively build the alien world without overwhelming exposition. The dialogue, particularly in the confrontation with Minister Kelyr, carries the philosophical weight characteristic of Le Guin's work. Lines like "Earth fears what it does not control" and "the future belongs to those who shape it" echo her tendency to embed political and philosophical ideas within character interactions. However, there are some weaknesses. While the piece avoids being completely predictable, the structure follows a somewhat expected diplomatic fiction formula. The market scene, while evocative, relies on familiar tropes of the wise local offering insight to the outsider. The conflict between what Senna observes and what they've been told is established but not deeply explored within this chapter. The character of Kelyr, while serving his narrative function, lacks some of the surprising complexity found in Le Guin's antagonists. His testing of Senna proceeds along predictable lines, and his motivations remain somewhat opaque beyond the standard colonial independence narrative. The prose occasionally becomes slightly overwrought, particularly in descriptive passages about the market. While Le Guin's writing can be lyrical, it typically maintains a certain spareness that this piece sometimes misses. Overall, this is a competent emulation of Le Guin's style and thematic concerns, successfully establishing a science fiction scenario that explores cultural divergence and political tension. It creates a believable alien setting and captures the philosophical underpinnings that would be present in Le Guin's work, though it doesn't quite reach the depth or originality of her best writing. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 80.9
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
# **Polymerase Chain Reaction** The glow-in-the-dark mushrooms had spread again. Neon green caps clustered along the cracks in the tile floor, feeding off the chemical residue of splicing experiments long past. Mira crouched, scraping one into a vial, watching as it pulsed faintly in the dim light of her lab. A failure, technically—she’d been aiming for edible luminescent fungi, but they turned out mildly toxic. Still, the glow was useful. She stood, stretching, feeling the ache in her back. Too much time hunched over salvaged lab equipment, coaxing life out of DNA that wasn’t meant to last. A knock at the reinforced door. Three sharp raps, a pause, then one more. The client. Mira pulled the heavy latch and swung it open. A man stepped in, his breath misting in the cold, his jacket patched with heat-sealed polymer. He smelled of smoke and engine oil, the scent of someone who dealt in the remains of the old world. "You’re late," Mira said, locking the door behind him. "Had to take the long way," he muttered. "MilSec drones overhead." Mira frowned. The old corporate security forces still patrolled, even though the corporations themselves had collapsed. Ghosts in powered armor, enforcing laws that no longer mattered. The man set down a metal case, unlatching it. Inside, sealed in cryo-gel, were vials of genetic material. "Last batch didn’t take," he said. "We need something stable." Mira sighed. That was the problem, wasn’t it? Before everything fell apart, engineered crops had been designed to die out after one generation. Built-in obsolescence, forcing buyers to return for new seeds every season. It was fine when the supply chains worked. Now, it was a death sentence. She picked up one of the vials, rolling it between her fingers. The genetic code inside was degrading. She could already see the faint clouding in the suspension, the telltale sign of DNA breaking down. "This is barely viable," she said. "You want food out of this, I’ll have to splice in something fresh." "Can you do it?" Mira exhaled. She had to. She moved to her workstation—a Frankenstein’s monster of salvaged biotech. A PCR machine with a cracked display, its thermal cycler jury-rigged with scavenged heating elements. A centrifuge missing its outer casing, humming dangerously when it spun. A gene sequencer with one working port, held together with epoxy and desperation. She loaded the sample, fingers moving with the precision of someone who had done this too many times. The machine beeped, struggling through the process. Mira tapped her foot, watching readouts flicker on an ancient monitor. The sequence was a mess—gaps where the DNA had crumbled, fragments barely holding together. "Shit," she muttered. The man watched her, arms crossed. "Problem?" "Not one I can’t fix," she said, more confidently than she felt. She reached for a backup sample—a strain of wild wheat she’d been cultivating in the settlement. Hardy, but slow-growing. If she could splice its resilience into the engineered crop, she might get something that wouldn’t die after one season. Mira worked quickly, fingers stained with reagent dyes, eyes burning from too many hours under flickering fluorescent lights. She prepped the new sequence, loaded it into the old gene gun—an ugly, battered device that hissed as it pressurized. A test batch. She fired the modified DNA into a tray of nutrient gel, watching as the cells absorbed their new instructions. Now came the waiting. She wiped her hands on her coat, turning back to the man. "Give it a few days. If it takes, you’ll have seeds that won’t die on you." He nodded, but didn’t leave. "There’s something else." Mira raised an eyebrow. "I don’t do weapons." "It’s not a weapon," he said. "It’s medicine." That word made her stomach twist. Mira gestured to the cot in the corner. "Sit." He hesitated, then did as she asked, rolling up his sleeve. The skin of his forearm was marked with old injection scars. Genetic treatments. Not the kind from before the collapse—those were too expensive, too rare. No, these were the rough kind, the kind people like Mira cooked up in backroom labs. He pulled a vial from his pocket, setting it on the table. The liquid inside was cloudy, the way bad gene mods got when they started breaking down. "Got this on the black market," he said. "Supposed to boost immune response. Worked, for a while. Now I think it’s killing me." Mira swore under her breath. She’d seen this before. The mods weren’t stable. They worked for a time, then turned against the body, breaking it down at the cellular level. She grabbed a lancet, pricking his finger, drawing a drop of blood. Under the microscope, she saw the damage—mutations spiraling out of control, cells struggling to replicate properly. "You need a counter-sequence," she said. He smirked. "That gonna cost extra?" Mira didn’t laugh. She turned back to her equipment, already scanning through her salvaged genomes. There were risks—untested modifications, unknown side effects. But in this world, you either adapted, or you died. She found what she needed: a sequence pulled from an old corporate longevity project. Designed to slow cellular decay, meant for the ultra-rich who never wanted to age. She loaded the sequence into her injector, dialing back the dose. No telling what a full treatment would do. "This might help," she said. "Or it might do something worse." He held out his arm. Mira pressed the injector to his skin and pulled the trigger. A sharp hiss. A flinch. Then, silence. The man flexed his fingers. "Feels the same." "Give it time," Mira said. He stood, rolling down his sleeve. "You ever take any of this stuff yourself?" Mira hesitated. Then she pulled down her own sleeve, revealing the faint bioluminescent veins running just beneath her skin. A side effect from an old experiment—a failed attempt at photosynthetic blood. "Yeah," she said. "I have." He nodded, understanding. No one in this world got out unchanged. He picked up the case, then paused. "If this works, we’ll be back." Mira exhaled. "I’ll be here." He left, and she locked the door behind him. The glow-in-the-dark mushrooms pulsed faintly in the darkness.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk short story effectively creates a post-apocalyptic world where genetic engineering has collapsed, leaving humanity to deal with the consequences of corporate greed. The author has crafted a compelling scenario featuring Mira, a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to create viable food crops from degrading genetic material. The worldbuilding is strong, with vivid details about jury-rigged lab equipment like "a PCR machine with a cracked display" and "a centrifuge missing its outer casing, humming dangerously when it spun." These details establish both the setting and the desperate circumstances without excessive exposition. The black market contract element is well-integrated, with a mysterious client seeking both viable crops and medical treatment. The narrative effectively shows the physical toll of genetic modifications through both the client's condition and Mira's own bioluminescent veins—a nice touch that reveals her personal stakes in this world. The prose is generally clean and effective, with some particularly strong imagery like the opening with glow-in-the-dark mushrooms. The author balances technical terminology with accessible descriptions, making the science feel authentic without overwhelming the reader. However, there are some weaknesses. The dialogue, while serviceable, lacks distinctive character voices. Both Mira and her client speak in similar terse patterns. The character development is somewhat limited—we learn little about Mira's background or motivations beyond her immediate circumstances. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels somewhat abrupt and doesn't fully resolve the tension established earlier. The story also doesn't fully explore the "unexpected upsides" of genetic modifications mentioned in the prompt. While Mira's bioluminescent veins are mentioned, their practical benefits aren't clearly established. The narrative could have delved deeper into how these modifications have changed society or provided unexpected advantages. Overall, this is a strong piece that effectively establishes a compelling biopunk setting and central conflict. With more character depth and a more developed resolution, it could be even stronger. + Iteration 2 — Avg Score: 82.0
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 69.3
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 5: The Invitation** The transfer vessel's air filtration system hummed with a persistent mechanical drone, a sound Arthur Neegan found both monotonous and oddly reassuring. He sat stiffly in the acceleration chair, his wrists resting on the armrests as if they might be clamped down at any moment. Opposite him, two figures clad in the midnight-blue uniforms of the Antares Diplomatic Corps sat impassively. Their insignia—a stylized red sunburst over a silver hemisphere—gleamed under the dim cabin lights. Diplomatic, indeed. Arthur had lived on Mars long enough to know that Antares was a hammer, and men like him were mere nails. The vessel shuddered slightly as it adjusted course. Through the narrow viewport, the ochre surface of Mars receded, replaced by the cold vastness of space. Arthur swallowed, wondering just what he had gotten himself into. The taller of his escorts, a man with close-cropped silver hair and a scar that ran from his temple to his jaw, finally spoke. His voice was smooth, measured. "You are about to meet an individual of significance, Mr. Neegan. I suggest you listen carefully." Arthur exhaled slowly. "I’d appreciate knowing who this individual is before I step into whatever you're about to throw me into." The second officer, a woman with sharp features and calculating eyes, smirked. "You'll know soon enough." The vessel docked seamlessly with a larger ship—one Arthur didn’t recognize, but its sleek, gunmetal-gray hull suggested it was something more than a simple diplomatic cruiser. Within moments, he was ushered through a series of sterile corridors, his boots echoing against the deck plating. He noted the subtle details—reinforced bulkheads, automated defense modules recessed into the walls. A warship, then, flying under the pretense of diplomacy. Finally, they arrived at a circular chamber, its walls lined with vast screens displaying tactical readouts, planetary maps, and streams of data in languages Arthur couldn’t decipher. At the center of the room stood a single figure: a man dressed in a high-collared black uniform, his hands clasped behind his back as he examined a holographic projection of Martian mineral deposits. The man turned as Arthur entered, revealing a face lined with experience but not yet worn by age. His eyes, dark and assessing, studied Arthur for a measured moment before he spoke. "Mr. Neegan. Welcome aboard the *Indomitable*." Arthur crossed his arms. "I don't recall accepting an invitation." The man smiled faintly. "No, you didn’t. But you’ll find that refusing certain invitations is... unwise." He gestured to a chair at the center of the room. "Sit, please." Arthur hesitated, then complied. He was out of his depth, and he knew it. The man remained standing. "I am Director Alastair Rho, representing certain interests within the Antares Consortium." He tapped a control panel, and the holographic display shifted, showing a detailed composition analysis of Azra. "You are sitting atop one of the richest Azra veins ever discovered, Mr. Neegan. That makes you a very valuable man." Arthur leaned back, feigning nonchalance. "Funny. A week ago, I was just another engineer looking to carve out a living. Now I’ve got armed escorts and veiled threats." Rho chuckled. "You misunderstand. This isn’t a threat. It’s an opportunity." He gestured to the holographic display again. "Azra, as you surely know, accelerates nuclear decay. The implications are vast—faster interstellar drives, more efficient energy production. And, of course, weaponization." Arthur nodded slowly. "And you want to ensure that vein ends up in the right hands. Your hands." Rho inclined his head. "You’re quick. Yes, Mr. Neegan, control over that deposit will determine the balance of power in this sector for the next century. The Consortium intends to secure it—preferably, with your cooperation." Arthur exhaled, weighing his words. "And if I refuse?" Rho's expression remained unreadable. "Then we will find another way. But I suspect you’d rather be an active participant in shaping the future rather than a casualty of it." Arthur's mind raced. He had no illusions—Antares wasn’t the only faction interested in his claim. He had already received coded messages from corporate representatives, shadowy intermediaries hinting at alliances and counteroffers. If Antares was moving this aggressively, then the stakes were higher than he had imagined. "Let’s assume I’m interested," Arthur said carefully. "What exactly are you offering me?" Rho smiled. "A stake in the operation. Full security clearance. Financial incentives beyond anything you’ve imagined. And, most importantly, protection." "Protection from whom?" Rho’s smile faded. "Everyone." Arthur let silence hang between them. He glanced at the holographic projection, at the swirling data that represented his future. He had come to Mars for stability, for the quiet dignity of honest work. Now, he sat at the fulcrum of an interstellar power struggle. Finally, he met Rho’s gaze. "I need time to think." Rho nodded. "Very well. But time is a luxury, Mr. Neegan. Others are moving even as we speak. Consider your position carefully." Arthur stood. "I always do." As he was escorted back to the transfer vessel, he couldn’t shake the feeling that no matter what choice he made, the game had already begun—and he was merely another piece on the board.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece attempts to capture Asimov's style in a sci-fi scenario involving Azra mining on Mars. The author has created a tense diplomatic encounter that follows the prompt's requirements, but with mixed success in emulating Asimov's distinctive approach. The chapter effectively establishes the scenario of Arthur being taken to meet Director Alastair Rho aboard the Indomitable. The setting is appropriately futuristic with details like holographic displays and interstellar politics. The dialogue-heavy approach matches the prompt's request, and there are attempts at world-building through references to the Antares Consortium and the implications of Azra technology. However, the writing lacks some of Asimov's hallmark characteristics. Asimov's work typically features clear, straightforward prose with an emphasis on logical progression and scientific concepts. This piece leans more heavily on atmospheric description and tension-building than Asimov typically would. While there are hints of the larger political landscape, the world-building lacks the depth and systematic explanation that characterizes Asimov's work. The dialogue is functional but not particularly distinctive. It conveys the necessary information but doesn't showcase the intellectual sparring or logical debates that Asimov excelled at. Characters speak in somewhat generic thriller-style exchanges rather than the more measured, intellectually-driven conversations typical of Asimov. The descriptive elements are sometimes overwrought, with phrases like "a face lined with experience but not yet worn by age" feeling more contemporary than classic sci-fi. Asimov would typically use more economical descriptions focused on functionality rather than literary flourish. The character of Arthur is somewhat passive throughout the encounter, primarily reacting to Rho rather than demonstrating the problem-solving mindset common to Asimov protagonists. The political intrigue is presented in broad strokes rather than with the intricate detail Asimov might have employed. While the piece does establish stakes and hints at larger conflicts, it doesn't fully capture the "big-and-small-picture world building" mentioned in the prompt. Asimov would typically connect the immediate scenario to broader historical and sociological contexts, often through exposition that this piece lacks. The ending effectively sets up future conflict but doesn't provide the intellectual satisfaction or twist that might be expected from an Asimov chapter conclusion. Overall, this is a competent sci-fi scene that follows the basic requirements of the prompt but doesn't fully capture Asimov's distinctive style, logical focus, or depth of world-building. + Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 82.0
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Darkroom Revelations** The red light hums above us, casting Elliot’s sharp cheekbones in soft shadow. I’ve always loved the way he exists in contrasts—his thrifted lace cuffs against the ink-black polish on his nails, the delicate way he handles a camera despite the steel rings on his fingers. He moves like he’s unsure if he’s allowed to take up space, but when he does, it’s deliberate. Careful. Beautiful. I tell myself I’m just intrigued. That’s all. “Pass me the developer?” I ask, breaking the silence that’s settled like dust in the dim room. Elliot nods and slides the tray toward me, his fingers brushing mine for a second before he pulls away. He’s always been like this—tentative, like he’s waiting for permission to exist fully. We work in tandem, the quiet only broken by the soft swish of photo paper sliding into liquid. Our final project is ambitious—double exposures, layering textures and bodies, playing with the boundaries between identity and perception. It was my idea, but Elliot had agreed, his dark eyes flickering with something hesitant yet eager. “I, um…” he starts, then stops, exhaling. I glance at him, and he’s staring at the curling edge of a print, his lip caught between his teeth. “What’s up?” I ask, keeping my voice even. I’ve learned that if I push too hard, Elliot folds inward like a closed book. He hesitates, then says, “I’ve been thinking a lot about—about gender. My gender, I guess.” Something flutters in my chest, unexpected and soft. I set down the tongs carefully. “Yeah?” Elliot nods, his fingers fidgeting with the chain around his neck. “I don’t know exactly what it means yet. But I feel… wrong, sometimes. In my body. Or maybe just in how people see me.” I lean against the counter, watching him. I’ve always been the kind of person who knows what they want, who moves through the world with certainty. But right now, I don’t know what the right thing to say is. I want to protect him, to hold space for him, but I also want to understand why this admission makes something shift inside me. “How long have you felt like this?” I ask, voice quieter than usual. “A while.” He swallows. “I just never had the words for it. Or maybe I was scared to say them out loud.” I nod slowly. I get that. Naming something makes it real. Elliot exhales, eyes flicking up to meet mine. “You’re the first person I’ve told.” The weight of that settles between us, warm and fragile. I could tell him I’m honored, but that feels too formal. Too distant. Instead, I just hold his gaze and say, “Thank you for trusting me.” He nods, and for a moment, it feels like something is shifting in the air between us. I’ve always been the one who takes charge, especially in relationships—choosing the restaurant, initiating the first kiss, leading the way. But with Elliot, everything feels delicate in a way I don’t quite know how to navigate. The silence stretches, thick and charged. Then, suddenly, the door creaks open slightly, and a sliver of white light spills in. “Shit—” I lunge for the stack of photo paper, but it’s too late. The exposure is instant, rendering the sheets useless. Elliot groans, pressing the heels of his hands to his eyes. “Fuck. That was all we had left.” I sigh, rubbing my forehead. “It’s fine. We’ll figure something out.” He looks at me, frustration flickering in his gaze. “You don’t have to pretend it’s fine just to make me feel better.” I smirk, crossing my arms. “Who says I’m pretending?” Elliot huffs out a laugh, shaking his head. “You’re something else, Dani.” I raise a brow. “You say that like it’s a bad thing.” “It’s not,” he says quickly, then hesitates. His fingers twitch at his sides before he tucks them into his pockets. “I just… wish I had that kind of certainty.” I study him, the way his shoulders curve inward, the way he holds himself like he’s afraid of taking up too much space. I’ve spent the last semester watching him, fascinated by how he balances softness with sharp edges, how he defies the usual definitions I’ve relied on. And now, with him standing here, vulnerable and open, I realize that my attraction to him isn’t just intrigue. It’s something deeper. Something terrifying. I’ve always been drawn to people who fit neatly into boxes—bold masculinity, defined femininity. But Elliot is standing in the in-between, and suddenly, I don’t know where that leaves me. “Certainty is overrated,” I say finally. “You don’t have to have everything figured out right now.” Elliot exhales, the tension in his shoulders easing just a little. “Yeah. Maybe.” The air between us shifts again, something unspoken stretching taut. I don’t know if it’s the red light casting everything in intimacy or the way Elliot is looking at me—like he’s waiting, like he wants me to move first. And normally, I would. But this time, I don’t. I let the moment hang, let him decide if he wants to close the distance. And when he finally does—when his fingers graze mine, hesitant but deliberate—I don’t pull away.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the intimate atmosphere of a darkroom encounter between Dani and Elliot, with the red light creating the confessional space requested in the prompt. The narrative successfully portrays Dani as an assertive character who finds herself in unfamiliar territory when confronted with Elliot's gender identity questioning. The characterization of Dani is consistent with the prompt - she's presented as someone who typically takes charge in relationships but is now navigating a situation where her usual approach feels inappropriate. Her internal struggle between wanting to protect Elliot's vulnerability while also questioning what his revelation means for her own identity is well-executed. The line "I've always been drawn to people who fit neatly into boxes—bold masculinity, defined femininity. But Elliot is standing in the in-between, and suddenly, I don't know where that leaves me" directly addresses this conflict. Elliot's characterization aligns with the prompt's description - his "soft demeanour," "quiet intellect," and unconventional style are all referenced. The narrative captures his tentative nature and vulnerability when sharing his gender questioning. The prose is generally strong, with effective imagery that establishes the darkroom setting and the physical presence of both characters. Descriptions like "the red light hums above us, casting Elliot's sharp cheekbones in soft shadow" and observations about his "thrifted lace cuffs against the ink-black polish on his nails" create a vivid picture while reinforcing the theme of contrasts and boundaries. The dialogue, though limited, feels natural and serves to advance both character development and plot. The conversation about gender identity is handled with appropriate weight and awkwardness, reflecting the "tender awkwardness" requested in the prompt. Where the piece falls somewhat short is in fully exploring the "complex attraction" mentioned in the prompt. While Dani acknowledges her attraction and confusion, the narrative could delve deeper into her specific feelings about Elliot's gender questioning and what it means for her own sexual identity. The ending, while showing a shift in their dynamic with Dani allowing Elliot to take initiative, feels slightly rushed and could benefit from more emotional depth. The accidental exposure of the photo paper creates a nice metaphor for vulnerability and exposure in their relationship, but this incident somewhat distracts from the central emotional thread rather than enhancing it. Overall, the piece successfully captures the requested scenario and characters, with strong prose and a good balance of internal reflection and external action. It effectively portrays the beginning of a shift in their relationship dynamic, though it could go further in exploring the complexities of Dani's attraction and identity questions. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 78.0
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Stolen Moments in Roma** --- ### **Scene 1: Collision Course** Ben had been so engrossed in his guidebook that he barely registered the roar of the motorcycle before it was nearly on top of him. The world blurred—pages flipping, a sharp inhale, the unmistakable screech of brakes. He barely managed to stumble backward as the bike swerved, missing him by inches. The rider cursed in rapid, musical Italian, her voice a sharp contrast to the hum of the Roman afternoon. "Sei cieco?!" she snapped, yanking off her helmet. A cascade of dark curls tumbled free, framing a face alight with irritation and something dangerously close to amusement. Ben blinked, his heart still hammering. "I-I—Mi dispiace! I didn’t see—" "Clearly!" she cut in, eyes flicking over him. "You tourists, sempre con i libri—" She snatched the guidebook from his hands, flipping through it with exaggerated interest. "Ah, sì. ‘The Hidden Secrets of Rome.’ Very original." Ben's face flushed. "Well, I like to be thorough." She smirked, tossing the book back to him. "Thorough will get you killed in this city, professore." "I'm not—well, actually, I am—" He faltered. "On sabbatical. From Cambridge." She tilted her head, considering him. "Ah. Un inglese. That explains the apologizing." Ben opened his mouth, but she was already sliding her helmet back on. "Try not to die, Cambridge," she called over the rumble of her engine, before speeding off into the chaos of Rome. He exhaled, dazed. The dented side panel of her motorcycle flashed in the afternoon sun before disappearing into the crowd. --- ### **Scene 2: A Reckless Invitation** Ben had just found his footing again—mentally and physically—when the same motorcycle skidded back to a stop beside him. "Allora, professore," she said, lifting her visor. "Do you want to see the real Rome, or do you want to keep reading about it?" Ben hesitated. He was a man of schedules, of carefully considered itineraries. But something about the challenge in her dark eyes unsettled him in a way that was both thrilling and deeply unwise. "This isn't some elaborate attempt to run me over properly, is it?" he asked dryly. She grinned. "No promises." Against all better judgment, he swung a leg over the bike. --- ### **Scene 3: The Art of Theft** The first stop was a tiny espresso bar, tucked between two weathered buildings. Alessandra ordered them both a caffè, downing hers in a single shot while Ben gingerly sipped his, eyes watering at the bitterness. She watched him struggle with a smirk. "Too strong for the delicate English stomach?" Ben cleared his throat. "I’m simply… savoring it." "Mm." She set her cup down and, with a casual flick of her wrist, pocketed a silver spoon from the saucer. Ben blinked. "Did you just—" She pressed a finger to her lips, eyes dancing with mischief. "Shh. A souvenir." "That’s—" He glanced around, lowering his voice. "That’s stealing!" She shrugged. "It’s just a little game. Rome takes from me, I take from Rome. Equilibrio, no?" Ben was torn between disapproval and something dangerously close to admiration. --- ### **Scene 4: Breaking and Entering (Sort Of)** Somehow, they ended up on the rooftop of an old palazzo, Alessandra having charmed—or distracted—the guard at the entrance. Rome sprawled beneath them in golden hues, the dome of St. Peter’s glowing in the late afternoon light. Ben exhaled in quiet awe. "This is incredible." She leaned back against the ledge, watching him instead of the view. "You don’t do this often, do you?" "What, trespass?" "No. Forget the rules." Ben hesitated. "I… prefer structure." She made a face. "Structure is just another way to stay safe. Too safe." "And you don't like safe?" She exhaled, a flicker of something unreadable in her expression. Then, suddenly, she grinned and pulled something from her pocket. Ben squinted. "Is that—?" "A key," she confirmed. "To the guard’s office. I borrowed it." Ben stared at her. "You mean you stole it." "Borrowed. Temporarily." She tossed it to him. "Want to return it, Cambridge? Or do you want to see what else we can get away with?" He caught it. And, to his own surprise, he didn’t return it. --- ### **Scene 5: The Trevi Confession** As dusk settled over the city, they found themselves back at the Trevi Fountain, its waters shimmering in the twilight. Ben dug into his pocket, fishing out a coin. "You’re supposed to throw it over your left shoulder, right?" Alessandra laughed. "Do you really believe in that nonsense?" He considered her. "Do you believe in anything?" Her smile faltered just slightly. Then, with a shrug, she plucked the coin from his fingers and tossed it into the fountain herself. "Now you have to come back," she said, a ghost of something unreadable in her voice. Ben didn’t know if she meant to Rome. Or to her. --- ### **Scene 6: A Reckless Goodbye** The day ended where it had begun—beside her motorcycle, the dented panel glinting under the streetlights. Ben hesitated. "This was—unexpected." Alessandra smirked. "That’s the best kind of day." He wanted to say something else, something meaningful. But she was already straddling the bike, fastening her helmet. "Ci vediamo, Cambridge." And then she was gone, vanishing into the night, leaving behind nothing but the scent of leather and gasoline. Ben stood there for a long moment, his structured world tilted just slightly off its axis. And in his pocket, where his coin should have been, sat a small, silver spoon. --- **End of Part One.**
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The piece "Stolen Moments in Roma" effectively captures a day-long encounter between two contrasting characters in Rome. The author has structured the narrative as a series of six interconnected scenes that follow Ben, a British academic, and Alessandra, a Roman motorcycle courier with kleptomaniac tendencies. The writing demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements. The characters match their descriptions—Ben is indeed portrayed as overly polite and somewhat out of his element, while Alessandra embodies the "fiery, independent" spirit requested. The narrative successfully incorporates Alessandra's kleptomania through subtle acts (stealing the spoon, "borrowing" the key) rather than explicit statements. The structure of short, vivid scenes works well to create a sense of a whirlwind day in Rome. The prose is generally elegant and flows naturally, with effective use of sensory details that immerse the reader in the Roman setting. Descriptions like "a cascade of dark curls tumbled free" and "Rome sprawled beneath them in golden hues" create vivid imagery without becoming purple or overwrought. The author balances description with action and dialogue effectively. The dialogue is one of the stronger elements, revealing character through speech patterns and word choice. Alessandra's "Sei cieco?!" and Ben's stammered apologies immediately establish their contrasting personalities. The dialogue feels natural and serves to advance both character development and plot. However, the piece has some weaknesses. While the characters are distinct, they verge on stereotypical at times—the uptight Englishman and the fiery Italian woman are somewhat predictable character types. The narrative could benefit from more surprising elements or deeper complexity in their personalities. The chemistry between them develops a bit too quickly and predictably, with Ben's attraction to Alessandra's free spirit following a familiar trajectory. The ending, while poetic with the silver spoon in Ben's pocket, feels slightly rushed. The emotional development between the characters could use more nuance—we understand Ben is "smitten," but Alessandra's feelings remain too enigmatic, making their connection feel somewhat one-sided. The piece successfully creates a sense of place, with Rome serving as more than just a backdrop. However, some opportunities to deepen the setting through more specific cultural details are missed. Overall, this is a competent and engaging piece of romantic fiction that fulfills the prompt requirements. It creates a clear sense of two contrasting personalities drawn together over the course of a day, with enough tension and chemistry to suggest a promising beginning to a larger story. With more surprising character moments and deeper emotional complexity, it could move from good to exceptional. + Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 82.8
Prompt:
Cozy spacepunk The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 4: A Stranger in the Fog** A glass shatters somewhere behind me. I don’t even jump—just another night at *The Last Outpost*. Someone will clean it up. Probably me. For now, I’ve got a customer in front of me, and they look like they’ve been through a meteor shower. “Vega whisky, neat.” Their voice is low, steady, but something in the way they say it—like every word is a weight they’re barely holding up—pricks at the back of my mind. “Better make that a double.” I nod, reaching for the bottle. The stranger’s tentacled dreads are a mess, some of them frayed at the ends, like they’ve been through fire. Their jacket—pilot’s leather, old but sturdy—is scuffed and stained with something dark. Not blood, I hope. I pour the whisky, sliding the glass across the bar. “Rough night?” I ask. They snort softly. “Rough week.” I lean on my elbows, watching as they take the first sip. They don’t wince, don’t even blink. Just let the burn settle in, then exhale slow. “Name’s Nets,” I offer. “You got a name, or should I just call you ‘Whisky’?” They glance up at me, eyes a deep, dark blue—like the space between galaxies. “Rho.” “Nice to meet you, Rho.” I flick a glance toward their jacket. “Looks like you’ve had a close encounter with something unpleasant.” A shadow crosses their face, but they just take another sip. “You could say that.” I wait. Silence is a bartender’s best tool. If you wait long enough, people fill the void. Sure enough, Rho exhales again, rubbing a hand over their face. “I need a place to lay low. Just for a few days.” I raise a brow. “Lay low from what?” They hesitate. “People.” The Outpost isn’t exactly a high-security hideaway. It’s a drift-stop, a place for miners, merchants, and misfits to catch their breath before heading back into the void. Not the kind of place you hole up in if you’re running from something serious. “You in trouble?” I ask, keeping my voice light. “I’m trying not to be.” Not exactly reassuring. I glance around the bar. Mostly regulars tonight, plus a few newcomers I clocked when they walked in. No one seems to be paying Rho much attention—yet. “You got creds?” I ask. They slide a small chip across the counter. I scan it, eyebrows lifting at the balance. More than enough for a room, drinks, and probably a few bribes if things got messy. “Alright,” I say, pocketing the chip. “I can get you a room. But if you bring heat down on this place—” “I won’t.” Their voice is firm, but there’s something underneath it. Something that sounds a lot like doubt. I sigh. “Fine. You eat?” Rho blinks, like they hadn’t considered it. I jerk my chin toward the kitchen. “I’ll get you something. Stay put.” I step away, slipping through the back door into the kitchen where Jex, our cook, is half-heartedly poking at something that might be stew. They glance up, antennae twitching. “New friend?” they ask. “Something like that,” I mutter, grabbing a bowl. “Got a bad feeling, though.” Jex snorts. “You always have a bad feeling.” I ladle some of the maybe-stew into the bowl. “Yeah, and I’m usually right.” Jex doesn’t argue. When I get back to the bar, Rho is staring into their drink, shoulders tense. I set the bowl in front of them. “Eat.” They blink at it, then at me. “You always feed your customers?” “Only the ones who look like they might keel over.” A ghost of a smile, but it doesn’t last. They pick up the spoon, take a bite. I watch as tension bleeds out of them just a little. The door hisses open. I glance up. Two figures step inside. I know trouble when I see it. Tall, armored, moving with the kind of confidence that says they’re used to people getting out of their way. One has a plasma pistol strapped to their thigh, the other a long, wicked-looking blade at their hip. They scan the room. Rho doesn’t look up, but I see their grip tighten on the spoon. I pick up a rag, start wiping the bar like I don’t have a pulse suddenly beating in my throat. “Friends of yours?” I murmur. Rho swallows hard. “Not exactly.” The two newcomers move toward the bar. I shift, casually stepping between them and Rho. “Evening,” I say, keeping my tone easy. “What can I get you?” The one with the blade smiles, but it doesn’t reach their eyes. “Looking for someone.” I tilt my head. “Lots of someones in here.” “This one’s special.” They lean on the bar, voice dropping. “Goes by Rho.” I don’t even glance back. “Can’t say I’ve heard the name.” The pistol-wielder narrows their eyes. “That so?” I smile, slow and lazy. “I hear a lot of names. Hard to keep track.” Behind me, Rho is still, too still. The blade-wielder taps their fingers on the counter. “See, I think you *have* heard it. And I think you’re stalling.” I shrug. “Maybe I just don’t like your tone.” The pistol-wielder shifts, hand resting on the grip of their weapon. Tension coils in my gut, but I keep my expression neutral. “You looking to start something?” Blade gives me another one of those cold smiles. “Not if we don’t have to.” I glance around the bar. People are watching now, quiet, waiting. Some of the regulars shift in their seats. I know who’s armed. I know who’d back me if things went south. I also know I don’t want a firefight in my bar. I look back at the two hunters. “Maybe you should take a walk.” Pistol tilts their head. “Maybe you should move aside.” Behind me, Rho exhales. And I know, in that instant, that things are about to get messy.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively establishes a cozy spacepunk atmosphere at "The Last Outpost" bar. The author has created a first-person present-tense narrative from Nets' perspective, capturing her voice as a bartender who's seen it all. The chapter introduces conflict through the mysterious stranger Rho and the two threatening figures who enter looking for them, creating narrative tension without resolution as requested. The writing demonstrates strengths in dialogue, which comprises roughly the requested 60% of the text. The conversations feel natural and reveal character through speech patterns and reactions. Nets' internal thoughts provide context while maintaining the present-tense perspective consistently. The worldbuilding is subtle but effective, with details like "tentacled dreads," "Vega whisky," and Jex's "antennae twitching" establishing the sci-fi setting without overwhelming exposition. The author creates a lived-in universe where different species coexist in this frontier-like outpost. Character development is handled well, particularly for Nets, whose bartender instincts and protective nature emerge naturally. Rho remains appropriately mysterious, revealing just enough to intrigue without exposing their full story. The antagonists are somewhat stock characters but serve their purpose as threatening presences. The prose is generally clean and functional, avoiding purple passages while still providing enough sensory detail to ground the reader. Occasional phrases like "eyes a deep, dark blue—like the space between galaxies" add color without becoming overwrought. Some weaknesses include slightly predictable plot development—the "stranger in trouble followed by pursuers" is a familiar trope—and limited physical description of the bar itself beyond functional elements. The ending confrontation, while creating tension, follows a somewhat expected trajectory. Overall, this is a solid chapter that establishes characters and conflict effectively while maintaining the requested tone and perspective. It successfully creates reader investment in what will happen next without resolving the immediate danger.
